summary: This is a sealed ex parte application by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, seeking a court order to disclose additional Jeffrey Epstein trust and estate documents (wills and trusts from 2001-2018) to a retained Yale Law School professor and Civil Division attorneys. The purpose is to obtain expert advice on potential government actions to protect its interests in the ongoing criminal investigation, potential forfeiture of Epstein's assets, and to address public policy concerns. The application references a prior similar order granted on December 20, 2019, and details the ongoing investigation into Epstein's associates and possible obstruction.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the sex trafficking investigation; his death by suicide in August 2019 is noted, but the investigation into his associates and his estate planning continues. His wills and trusts from 2001-2018 are the subject of the disclosure request.

persons.name: Denise Cote
persons.context: The judge who entered the prior disclosure order on December 20, 2019, related to an earlier set of Epstein trust documents. Her prior order is attached as Exhibit A.

events.title: $100,000 Wire Transfer

events.title: $250,000 Wire Transfer
events.description: Epstein wired $250,000 from the same trust account to another individual, a possible co-conspirator identified as an employee in the indictment.

keyFacts: The government's investigation into Epstein's associates and possible obstruction continued after his death, focusing on a network of wills and trusts created between 2001 and 2018.

Epstein made substantial wire transfers ($100,000 and $250,000) to individuals identified as possible co-conspirators in late November/early December 2018, shortly after damaging media reports, suggesting potential witness tampering.

The government sought to disclose eight prior wills and related trust documents (from 2001-2018) to a Yale Law School professor and Civil Division attorneys to evaluate potential forfeiture actions and public policy challenges to the estate plans.
Epstein's estate planning was extensive, with trusts intended to receive most of his assets, including properties identified as subject to criminal forfeiture.
The document reveals the government's strategy to use civil legal tools (trusts and estates law) to protect its interests in an ongoing criminal investigation and potential asset forfeiture.
